references: Lannoo, M. 2005. M. Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA (2005), p. 1094
Green, D.M., L.A. Weir, G.S. Casper, and M.J. Lannoo. 2013.  North American Amphibians: Distribution and Diversity.  University of California Press. Berkeley, California. 340 pp.
Crother, B. I. (ed.) 2012. Standard Common and Current Scientific Names for North American Amphibians, Turtles, Reptiles, and Crocodilians, Seventh Edition. Herpetological Circular 39: 1-92.
Baker, J. K. 1957. Eurycea troglodytes: a new blind cave salamander from Texas. Texas Journal of Science 9:328-336.

NatureServe. 2016. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://explorer.natureserve.org. (Accessed: March 22, 2016).
habitat_description: The Valdina Farms salamander was described from Valdina Farms Sinkhole in Medina County, Texas (Baker 1957). This species inhabits spring outflows of canyons of Bandera, Real, and Kerr counties. Some individuals have been observed in springs in the Sabinal River drainage (Green et al. 2013). Individuals inhabiting caves are found in the open, on mud substrate, or on rocks near spring outflows (Lannoo 2005; Green et al. 2013).
